nodes.text: @thesportstyle This type of mentality is reason we do not succeed as a people . Always on some dividing bs
@hopeispoweruk Have a good day.
@hopeispoweruk Stop your projection. Black people are not a monolith. Because I feel strongly about cultural consideration does not make me xenophobic. That’s just lazy, un-nuanced thinking.

@thesportstyle They are black people who are playing black characters. A black brit , french , American, Caribbean should be free to do so . Some black brits are descents of slaves , colonisation etc . Stop this xenophobia
@hopeispoweruk What about it? The argument remains: People should be telling their own stories about their heroes.
@thesportstyle @BlogXilla How about when black Americans play African characters and historic figures like Mandela , Winnie , Idi Amin etc.

@BlogXilla For generations, the images Black Americans saw of themselves (and were shared with the world) was of degradation, & when we’re finally in a better position to represent ourselves on screen with dignity, we can’t even do that, it hurts; it’s like being robbed of your culture.

@thesportstyle I understand that but this movie was made by a black director, a black man produced it, it was written by two black brothers and Kaluuya and LaKeith are top tier talent as you say. \n\nQuestion. Do you think the movie shouldn’t have been made?
@BlogXilla @thesportstyle The director isn't a Black American. That is the root of the problem.
@BlogXilla Sorry, I only care about ethnicity. And he's really not that great of an actor.
@BlogXilla An actor of the foundation black descent should have played  the lead. Not a British actor
@EvanMHarris See I think those are two different things. Cynthia is a great actress but I feel like she has to do more. Kaluuya IMO is a proven commodity.

@BlogXilla British actors are the best in the world. I don’t have any smoke for Daniel, he got it & he did great. All I’m saying is that a lot of African Americans don’t get decent chances and when a movie about an African American comes by, it goes to a black British actor lol

@BlogXilla Indeed. Many of these movies have some Black American person involved. And yes, it’s important for these films to be made. There is just a sensitivity and respect that people are missing when it comes to Black American culture. Everyone thinks they are entitled to it.

@BlogXilla No doubt, but why is it that African American stories can’t be told by African Americans? The lady who did Harriet was on Twitter coming for African Americans, like she wasn’t portraying one of the most famous ones on screen.

@BlogXilla There’s a lot of nuance being lost with this position. The issue isn’t with Black Brits. Kaluuya is a top-tier talent. The issue is the trend of Black Americans being de-centered from representing their own stories about historic Black American figures. That cannot be ignored.
@BlogXilla Same goes for most of these British cats, they’re just a different breed compared to our actors
@blahsquiat @BlogXilla @nbcsnl Lmao. Right.
@blahsquiat @BlogXilla That’s what @BlogXilla tweet was about. People are discounting him and his work because he’s not black American....so why did you....ok.

@Pomac @BlogXilla I never said he wasn't qualified. My only parsing was that Black & African are very different. Just like Nigerian and Ghanian or Puerto Rican and Dominican are very different. \n\nBy no means was I shitting on him as an actor. I think he's incredibly talented.

@blahsquiat @BlogXilla Black America is not a monolith. I know this as who went to a predominately black low income middle school and a New England boarding school with 1%ers. College in Philly with all types of black people. \n\nThe point is Daniel K was able and qualified to do this part.

@blahsquiat @BlogXilla Not only that but as someone who studies acting and is an actor, his work was incredibly strong. You don’t need Black American generational trauma to understand Fred Hamptons point. Hence rainbow coalition.
@BlogXilla I think the term “actor” my have went over some folks heads.

@blahsquiat @BlogXilla I lived in South Africa dont play me. We aren’t being politically correct when we say black and you know that. Don’t be a smart ass. Race is a construct. Don’t play this game with me sir. #WrongOne
@BlogXilla John David Washington on the come up too!
@blahsquiat @BlogXilla Black is not specific to the United States. But cool.
@blahsquiat I understand that. But we are all the same. It’s just like apples 🍎 🍏 they all still APPLES.

@BlogXilla Even apples have various phenotypes. Golden Delicious is not the same as Macintosh. By that theory, we'd all be African to begin with, no? \n\nGrape Varietals are probably a better metaphor. Riesling and Cabernet grapes produce completely different wines once they're fermented...
@BlogXilla People really will find something to dislike
@BlogXilla He bodied that role!! #Salute 💯✊🏾
@BlogXilla I hate when people split hairs like that
